intro: Cynanchum implicatum, commonly known as the hooked milkvetch, is a perennial herb native to arid and semi-arid regions of North America. It belongs to the family Asclepiadaceae, which includes milkweeds, and is characterized by its slender stems and opposite leaves. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers that bloom in summer, followed by distinctive, hooked fruits that aid in seed dispersal. Its latex contains toxic compounds, making it unpalatable to most herbivores. Cynanchum implicatum is often found in disturbed soils and is adapted to survive in harsh, dry environments.
